sa5:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa5:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa5:2.2: “When you don’t know or understand form and don’t become free of desire for it, the mind isn’t liberated.
sa5:2.3: When the mind isn’t liberated, it’s not possible to stop suffering.
sa5:2.4: Thus, when you don’t know or understand feeling … perception … volition … consciousness and don’t become free of desire for it, the mind isn’t liberated, and it’s not possible to stop suffering.
sa5:3.1: “Monks, if you know and understand form and become free of desire for it, the mind is liberated, and it’s possible to stop suffering.
sa5:3.2: Thus, if you know and understand feeling … perception … volition … consciousness and become free of desire for it, the mind is liberated, and it’s possible to stop suffering.”
sa5:4.1: When the monks heard what the Buddha taught, they rejoiced and approved.
